content.description:
The first linear piece begins at the origin, moves up to the right, and passes through the points with the following coordinates:

(1 comma 1)

(2 comma 2)

(3 comma 3)

The second linear piece starts where the first linear piece ends at the point (3 comma 3), moves up to the right, and passes through the points with the following coordinates:

(4 comma 5)

(5 comma 7)

The graph ends at the point (5 comma 7).

The graph of the piecewise-linear function <math alttext="f"><semantics><mi>f</mi><annotation encoding="application/vnd.wiris.mtweb-params+json">{"digitSeparatorsAsMN":"auto"}</annotation></semantics></math> is shown in the figure. Let <math alttext="g"><semantics><mi>g</mi><annotation encoding="application/vnd.wiris.mtweb-params+json">{"digitSeparatorsAsMN":"auto"}</annotation></semantics></math> be the inverse function of <math alttext="f"> <semantics> <mi>f</mi> <annotation encoding="application/vnd.wiris.mtweb-params+json">{"digitSeparatorsAsMN":"auto"}</annotation> </semantics> </math>.
content.question: What is the maximum value of <math alttext="g"> <semantics> <mi>g</mi> <annotation encoding="application/vnd.wiris.mtweb-params+json">{"digitSeparatorsAsMN":"auto"}</annotation> </semantics> </math> ?

skill.text: Skill 2.A: Identify information from graphical, numerical, analytical, and verbal representations to answer a question or construct a model, with and without technology.
